address.streetAddress: 19 Horticultural Ave Between Jarvis, Sherbourne, Dundas and Gerrard Sts.

description: Donated by a prominent local philanthropist, these gardens boast a beautiful glass-domed Victorian structure.

reviews.title: Lovely Gardens
text: This was a lovely conservatory, but it is small and is currently especially small because they are remodeling the middle part of the building. This means that the two open sections must both be visited separately. This place is clearly a labor of love for those who work here. The turtles in their pond and large goldfish in a separate one are highlights. the entire place was very lovely and serene. I recommend stopping here if in the area. I would love to see it again once it's fully open.

reviews.title: Nice spot if you're nearby
text: 4 greenhouses were open when we were there with the middle section being closed.  I'm not sure why but I expected it to be a little larger (if I'm remembering correctly they had approx 3 paths in each with plants on both sides so 5 rows (columns??) of plants with the length of the greenhouse being similar to what a grocery store plant center in spring may have (maybe a little longer??).

Given that and the fact that we didn't stop and study each plant it didn't take too long to go through the 4 greenhouses (I'm going to guess 30 minutes).  The orchid display was underwhelming as the orchids are in a small room in that greenhouse all by themselves and had 10-ish plants (i think), in pots like you'd buy orchids at a store.  Again nice but somehow not what i was expecting.  The rest of the displays were great.  Cactus (I think) growing horizontal near the ceiling and the house with water (koi and turtles included) were great.

One last thing, while we were there a local told us that this area of the city is where many of the social services and safe injection sites are located.  There were homeless people in the surrounding park but it's a big park and there were also many locals as there was a playground and dogpark in the park as well, so as long as you're aware you should be okay.

reviews.title: Stop in if you are nearby, but don’t make a special trip
text: This site is under construction. It was only possible to visit two small buildings. It was a nice, quick stop. Don’t make a special trip here right now. Not a lot to see while under construction.

reviews.title: Very safe and lovely visit
text: Some rooms are undergoing renovations but still lots to see.  It is free.  Looks like most of the homeless encampment is gone.  No issues there.  It is very safe to visit    It is open until 4:45 pm.  Only takes 45 minutes to see everything

reviews.title: For Travellers on a Budget!
text: The palm tree section of the gardens is under renovation currently (as of November 2023) so please be aware of that! However, the other 4 sections of the garden are open to the public and are outstanding. You don't need a ton of time here, but if you're into nature and plants at all, then this is a must-do. My fiancé and I loved it.
It's also free! So if you're in the city on a budget, this may be an activity worth checking out.

Yes, there is a homeless encampment in the park. We, however, did not experience any negative situations as a result of this. I would say this is important information to note, but don't avoid the park because of it. These people need a place to be, especially with winter approaching, and unfortunately they don't have any other options. Be kind and compassionate, and put yourself in their shoes rather than jumping to the worst conclusions.

reviews.title: Splenid Garden Area
text: Beautiful gardens and other things to see. They have so many varieties of plants and flowers to look at, a small waterwheel area with lots of turtles, a and a koi pond. I am not much of a nature person but this place was definitely worth seeing.

reviews.title: Homeless camp
text: Sadly the park is a no go area.  The conservatory is shut with fencing around it.  The park is a homeless camp.  I walked up there with my 15 yr old daughter and she was really sad a bit scared as we had to walk past several people who had collapsed on the pavement.  There were police and ambulances in the area.  I didn’t feel nervous however on return to our hotel the concierge said that his colleague had been punched on the way to work by a homeless person.  Cost of living crisis apparently.  Very sad.

reviews.title: Beautiful conservatory!
text: This conservatory was amazing. Lots of exotic plants to see, and even turtles as well. Would definitely visit again, especially once the middle section is rebuilt and open to the public.

reviews.title: Dangerous experiance
text: Dangerous dangerous dangerous ! Allen Gardens is a beautiful gem in the middle of a dystopian hellscape that is Toronto. It lures the unaware into the striking range of stabbers, homeless squatters, junkies the mentally ill and muggers. Rarely is there a police presence any where to be seen. Definitely a no go, especially after dark.

reviews.title: Watch your belongings
text: Just don't go to this neighborhood.
Crawling with all kinds of nasty people and traffic is horrible. Seriously. Toronto sucks

reviews.title: Beautiful world to explore
text: Free entrance to conservatory with little boards hidden away to explain what you see. Didn’t find anyone to explain the different areas but it’s still a beautiful place to visit. Saw the turtles sitting still and didn’t realize they were live till I found a bunch swimming out from under the water mill. Little decorative touches for Christmas, so not sure how that is different during summer months. Easy to get to with TTC (3 stops on the 75 bus from Sherbourne station, less than a min walk to park). Can see it all in an hour. Washroom on premises. Can use wheelchair but hard to navigate around some of the corners. Few benches around to sit and enjoy the view.

reviews.title: From Frigid to Equatorial
text: A not to be missed miracle in Toronto. You transition from a 'Feels like minus 23' zone to a summer in Arizona type landscape by crossing just one glass door. Along with Cacti you will find Christmas cheer in more than 30 types of Poinsettias !!! Eye candy for flora enthusiasts and photographers.

reviews.title: Refreshing little break from winter weather
text: Sweet greenhouses - one has a little pond with several very healthy-looking turtles swimming and crawling around.  The cyclamens are stunning.  We had a chance to speak with one greenhouse keeper who has loved her job there for seven years.  She explained how she chose the various displays and the autonomy she has.  That added to our experience.  This is a relatively small place (not like the Garfield Park Conservatory in Chicago) but is is free and refreshing change on a winter day.  It is free, but their website lists incorrect hours!  On the day we arrived (a Monday or Tuesday) it only opens at noon, not 10:00 so we stood around outside in the snow waiting for opening.

reviews.title: Beautiful Christmas Setting
text: We stopped off to see the gardens and to learn how they exhibit for the Holliday Season.  Certainly we went disappointed with a massive display of poinsettias and other seasonal flowers mingled in with the gardens massive tropical greenery.  Our only disappointment was not seeing an employee who could answers some if our questions but we later learned that there was a lady from the Gardens who some of our friends discovered who was very knowledgable.  If you have a couple of hours do drop in.

reviews.title: Something different
text: A friend who grew up in Toronto recommended this place, I wouldn’t have known about it otherwise. It was something thing different. The tropical plants were a strange contrast to the bleak grey looming outside. Then the cheeky squirrels were playing chasing games. It’s a part of town I might not have experienced if it was not recommended. I kinda liked the dog park next door more (who doesn’t like dogs right?).

reviews.title: Let’s get out of the urban jungle and take a rest where you can be in touch with nature.
text: This place is located near the center of Toronto. It is easy to visit.

The Greenhouse in the center of the garden is a good place to relieve your stress and tiredness. Flowers and trees provide some positive effects on air population and fine dust by supplying clean oxygen. And the greenhouse's are controlled humidity and temperature so, you'll feel cool.

This place is easy to visit regardless of weather and season. Sometimes it is changed into a shelter. It blocks the wind in winter and avoids the hot heat in summer. And here is where I can rest regardless of weather conditions. Also, if you're gotten a lack of sunlight in your indoor life, let's go to the glassy greenhouse. It is full of sunlight all day long. It's a great place to enjoy the sunshine communing with plants.
토론토 시내에서 위치해 방문하기 쉽고, 공원 중심에 있는 온실은 날씨 상관없이 즐기기 좋습니다. 온실은 총 6구역으로 나눠 있으며, 특정 시간에 해설사 설명을 들을 수도 있어 방문 전, 시간을 확인하고 가시면 좋을 것압나다.

reviews.title: Beauty in the City
text: We visited the Allan Gardens Conservatory which is a free attraction in Toronto.  We enjoyed it thoroughly even though we are not hardcore 'garden' people.  What a nice quiet place to enjoy the beauty of a huge variety of plants, trees and flowers in the city.  The buildings themselves are also pretty to look at.  No matter the season, it'd make a lovely place to visit.

reviews.title: SQUIRRELS AND FLOWERS GALORE
text: Allan Gardens is a very well laid out park with several different areas. It's well maintained and an oasis in the hustle and bustle that is the wonderful city of Toronto. Oh, and there squirrels everywhere as well. The conservatory is absolutely wonderful. Free to enter and with one of the most beautiful selections of flowers and plants you could image. Well laid out, extremely colourful and with so many different species. Plus there are resident squirrels in there too! Anyway you should visit if you can because it's a total delight.

reviews.title: Such a fantastic place
text: Have been fortunate enough to live in Toronto for two years and have visited this place a few times and each time have thought how wonderfully lucky residents and visitors are to have such a fantastic place that is free to enjoy and that is run by the City.

reviews.title: Love this place.
text: This place is free! And so beautiful all year around. The staff are so passionate about the various plants and flowers, and know a LOT. There are a few different microclimates, so different plants Super cool place!

reviews.title: Dangerous at night
text: The garden itself is good but the park and area is not safe at night. Sketchy people and drug addicts. Avoid at all cost.

reviews.title: Christmas Allan Gardens visit
text: My first trip to Allan Gardens & I don't know why I waited so long. It's an easy drive in from Oshawa. Parking meant circling the block a couple of times to find street parking. But beautifully decorated for the Christmas season it was a delight on a gloomy Saturday. The poinsettias & cyclamen were bright & seasonal. Lots of cacti & succulents & bulbs added to the colour. I will certainly be returning for the other seasonal displays as they change through the year. It isn't large but it also wasn't overly crowded. I did notice signs for children's workshops which would be interesting for a family group.

reviews.title: Tropical garden in the midst of winter-cold Toronto
text: This is one of the oldest gardens of the city, open year-round, and totally free. In contrast with the gloom outside, Allan Gardens offers the greenest sight right behind doors, along with a vast array of flowers and decorations. There are orchids, morning glories, peace lilies, a guava, bananas, areca trees, etc. This is a hidden gem with very few tourists, so one can enjoy an utmost tranquility while reading a book on one of the benches, surrounded by trees.

reviews.title: A Garden to Visit Even During the Winter
text: Getting to the Allan Gardens is very easy by using public transportation. It's open all year round and is free.

This indoor botanical garden is definitely an oasis in the city. It features six greenhouses: two tropical houses, the cool temperate house, the palm house, the tropical landscape house and the arid house.
There are lots of different types of plants to enjoy. My favourite things were the orchids, the cacti and succulents and the turtles I saw on a little pond.
Allan Gardens Conservatory is not a huge place, so you could easily spend half an hour there.

reviews.title: A Calm Oasis in the City (and it's free!)
text: If you have a little time on your hands and enjoy flowers and plants, head over to Allan Gardens. It's close to the College Street subway stop, so it's easy to get to. It's a calm oasis at any time of the year. The flowers/plants on display change throughout the year, and it's located in a lovely old glass conservatory. Take your time strolling through the various exhibits, and if you enjoy photography you will have fun snapping pics of the familiar and exotic plants and flowers. Best of all, it's free! And kid friendly (as long as you keep an eye on them and don't let them touch or pick the flowers).

reviews.title: A secret escape in the concrete jungle
text: When you step in the doors, you are transported out of the busy city into a little piece of flowery heaven.
Different sections of environment type have many varieties of beautiful plants. A wonderful little escape.

reviews.title: More than a Century old, this is a treasure
text: Established in 1858, Allan Gardens id a treasure. Walk into the greenhouses, under the "conservatory dome" and treat yourself to a wonderful display of the plants of the world and seawall showings.
By donation only, by City Order in 1858, this should be a must for anyone who wants a relaxing feel hours away from the hubbub of the City.

reviews.title: Beautiful place!
text: I was in Toronto for my daughter to attend a dance program at the National Ballet School of Canada and had a lot of downtime while she was dancing for 3 days.  I decided to explore some lesser known Toronto spots around the ballet area.  A friendly gal at Tim Hortons suggested Allan Gardens and I’m so glad she did.  I was pleasantly surprised to find out that admission was free and the walk around the park to the building was lovely.  As soon as I entered, it was as though I had transported to somewhere very different from the hustle and bustle of the city.  It was peaceful, warm, and absolutely beautiful.  I took my time and walked slowly though making sure to notice details and take it all in.  I loved the Christmas decor mixed in with the more permanent plant displays.  I especially loved the turtle pond and spent quite a bit of time watching them.  Overall I spent about 2 hours visiting with some of that just relaxing on a bench with my book.  I would definitely visit again when in Toronto and recommend it for all ages.

reviews.title: An oasis in the heart of the city
text: This is a unique treasure for all visitors. I love visiting in winter when I need a tropical getaway. The flora and fauna are beautiful year round and I love seeing the resident turtles splashing in their habitat. The architecture brings you back to a simpler time. What a gift to our city!

reviews.title: Tropical welcome on a chilly morning
text: My teens and I visited the Palm House and Conservatory on a chilly day after Christmas. What a warm welcome we received (and how surprised we were!) when we entered. It was beautifully festive with poinsettias and festive plants. There were many visitors of all ages there too, testament to the quality of the visit. Thanks!

reviews.title: Especially wonderful in the spring
text: When one is fed up with winter a visit here is very worthwhile. Entering one get the scents from all the spring flowers. It is also very peaceful and well maintained.

reviews.title: Disappointed - closed
text: Deeply disappointed. Beautiful building, but surrounded by trash and construction paraphernalia.  Although the website claimed it was open, it wasn’t. We were directed by a sign on one door and some people hanging around the neighborhood to walk around to another entrance, but nothing was open. Would have liked to see it, and would not have made the trip if we had known it was closed.

reviews.title: Allan Gardens Conservatory …… must visit.
text: Allan Gardens Conservatory…. One of the best places to visit on a rainy day. The wide variety of exotic plants growing in there, each one in their natural surroundings, so well created for their survival is very impressive.
A must-see place for all those who love gardening and who love this city of Toronto.
It truly lives upto the saying that all things beautiful in life are for free. Here the entry is FREE.

reviews.title: Beautiful flowers and plants
text: Going through major renovations at the moment. Not everything is available to see. Some plants are in need of Tender loving care.

reviews.title: Thumbs up!
text: I enjoyed walking through the the greenhouse and checking out the wide variety of plants here. My husband and I had a good time and enjoyed the peaceful environment. It’s currently under construction — it will definitely benefit from those improvements. I do wish I had seen some roses!

reviews.title: Very Cool Free Tropical Gardens
text: Allan Gardens seems a little run-down on the outside and there was only one staff person on site when we were there. But this is a 100% free thing to do in Toronto that is a little bit different. They have desert and tropical gardens, turtles, and koi fish, laid out in a nice walk between 3 or 4 greenhouses (there is a rental space that has good bones but it was under renovation when we went). It is hot inside, just to warn you - we went on a day when it was about 27 degrees outside so it was pretty sweaty in the “desert”! I love interesting plants and photographing flowers so if that’s something you like, this is worth heading over to. But maybe more of a rainy day activity :)

reviews.title: Oasis in the city
text: Allen Garden is right in downtown Toronto with very easy access. The conservatory is a beautiful architecture built more than 100 years ago. Inside the conservatory are different types of tropical plants and exotic flowers, don’t know how much effort it takes to grow these tropical plants here in cold Toronto. The conservatory isn’t huge but it’s definitely worth visiting.

reviews.title: Disappointing!!!!!!
text: Dear Sir/ Madam:  How hard is it to provide appropriate directions to your temporary entrance?  One walks entire back area that normal entrance sign instructs temporary entrance now located and yet there is no entrance.  Only entrance is for employees and construction but none for tax paying or anxious persons who what to see and experience the Conservatory.
You think you could but up some signs that reflect where entrance is located!!!!!!
Disappointing!!!!!

reviews.title: A visual delight at every turn
text: An absolutely beautiful place to stroll. A lot of gorgeous flowers. We had the pleasure of going here in March 2020, just before the Covid pandemic lockdown.

reviews.title: Oasis in Downtown Toronto
text: I didn't know what to expect and I was pleasantly surprised! We spent 30-60 minutes exploring the 5 themed areas: cactus, palms, etc. The gardens are beautiful and well maintained. The Conservatory is quiet and peaceful, with few visitors. We took pictures of neat plants and lovely displays. I highly recommend visiting the Conservatory if you're in the area!
